speech.para: Senator SPOONER(New South WalesVicePresident of the Executive Council and Minister for National Development). - Mr. President, may I take this opportunity, at least on behalf of honorable senators on the Government side - I believe I do it also on behalf of all honorable senators - of congratulating you upon your re-election as President of the Senate. It is a great thing to have been President of the Senate for as long a period as nine years and then to be re-elected for a further period of three years. I am sure it is something that you will look back upon throughout the rest of your life with great satisfaction and with very great pride indeed. We all congratulate you very sincerely.

I think also that we can take satisfaction in the thought that over the years in which you have held this very high office you have not only acquitted yourself to our satisfaction, as honorable senators bowing to your decrees from time to time, but have also done credit to the Senate in the responsibilities you have undertaken so successfully in the wider sphere of parliamentary work outside the Senate itself. I refer in particular to the fact that you held the very high and distinguished office of Chairman of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.

This is one of those occasions on which you hold not only the respect of the Senate but also the personal goodwill of all members on both sides of the Senate. I confess that we on this side of the Senate would rather wish that our numbers were a little greater than they are to-day, but we face that position and go into the next three years, as I think members of the Opposition do also, with confidence in the knowledge that you will discharge the responsibilities you assume as President of the Senate impartially and to the benefit of the Senate as a whole rather than to the benefit of any one particular group of senators.

Senator McKENNA(Tasmania - Leader of the Opposition). - Mr. President, may I take this opportunity to offer to you, on behalf of myself and my colleagues of the Opposition, our very sincere congratulations upon your re-election to the office of President. In view of our long and happy experience of your occupancy of the chair in the past, we of the Opposition are confident that you will continue to carry out the important duties of that office not only with distinction to yourself but also with complete satisfaction to all members of this chamber.

Senator ARNOLD(New South Wales).May I add my congratulations to you, Mr. President, on your re-election as President. It is a great honour to hold that office for the long period for which you have distinguished the Senate by holding it. You have given great service to the people of Australia. Although I feel that in this chamber there are 32 people who could be a little better educated, in the circumstances I am sure that my colleagues as well as the members of the Government parties realize that over the years you have given the Senate good leadership in the office of President. debateinfo.title: DEATH OF SENATOR THE HONORABLE ALBERT DAVID REID, M.C

talker.electorate: New South WalesVicePresident of the Executive Council and Minister for National Development
talker.name: SPOONER, William
Senator SPOONER

talk.start.para: - by leave - It is with regret that I advise the Senate of the death on 22nd May last of Senator the Honorable Albert David Reid, M-C. He was elected to the Senate as a senator for New South Wales at the general election in 1949. He was a Temporary Chairman of Committees from June, 1951, until March, 1953, and Vice-Chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works from June, 1951, until September, 1953. He was Chairman of Committees and a member of the Senate Standing "Orders Committee from September, 1953, until his death. He was a member of the parliamentary delegation to the Coronation of Her Majesty the Queen in 1953. Prior to being elected to the Senate he was a member of the Legislative Assembly of New South Wales and a Minister of the Crown of that State. I am sure, Mr. President, honorable senators will agree that this is not only a long record of public service but also a distinguished record in many spheres of activity.

speech.para: I think most honorable senators will remember that Senator Reid was one of the original members of the First Australian Light Horse Regiment. He served in the First and Fourth Australian Light Horse Regiments, rose to the rank of major, won the Military Cross and, in addition, was mentioned in despatches.

Senator Reidwas Chairman of Committees in this Senate for approximately nine years, and I venture the opinion that as a result of his temperament and long parliamentary experience in the State Parliament and in this Senate he was indeed a distinguished Chairman of Committees. But perhaps most of us will remember him even better as a friend and a loyal colleague. He was the type of man who was always ready to lend a helping hand. That helping hand was so valuable because it was supported by such a long period of experience and natural capacity. For my part, I shall always think of him as a Light Horse man. He seemed to have the simple philosophy that it was his task to do the job which was put before him.

We send our sympathy to his wife and family. We express the hope that the sadness they feel will be softened by the knowledge that all of us in this Senate thought so well of him and that, on his passing, he has left in this Senate a reputation which every one of us present would like to earn. I move -

quote.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death of the Honorable Albert David Reid, M.C, who was at the time of his death Chairman of Committees and Senator for the State of New South Wales, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its sincere sympathy to his widow and sons in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: . - On behalf of the Opposition, I second the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Spooner). The death of Senator the Honorable Albert George Reid on 22nd May last, just before he was due to retire from the Senate, closed the career of one who had given distinguished parliamentary service in the Parliament of the State of New South Wales and in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, as well as outstanding military service to his country in two world wars. Senator Spooner has given details of that service. I do not propose to repeat them, but I shall refer to them merely to offer a respectful and appreciative tribute from the Opposition.

speech.para: The eloquent testimonial paid at the funeral service by leaders of Senator Reid's church to his single-minded adherence to his Creator and His teachings, provided the key to the rectitude, the earnestness and personal integrity that strongly characterized Senator Reid for all of us down the whole of his twelve and a half years in this Senate. Efficient and quick as Senator Reid was as Chairman of Committees, he was always willing, on proper notice, to co-operate in giving the Opposition an opportunity to debate clauses of a bill in which it was particularly interested. Thanks to a close association with him in work at this table, I developed a great respect and friendly regard for him, and these feelings grew rather than lessened with occasional conflicts of opinion. One felt of Senator Reid that he had constantly before his mind the poet's lines -

We of the Opposition extend to Government members, particularly to members of the Australian Country Party, our condolences on the loss of their colleague. We offer to Senator Reid's widow and members of his family our sincere sympathy in their grievous loss and trust that they will find consolation in the thought that the great qualities which endeared Senator Reid to them were known to and appreciated by all on this side of the Senate.

talk.start.para: . - The Australian Country Party joins in the tributes that have been paid to the late Senator Albert Reid, whose death in Concord Repatriation Hospital on 22nd May last, less than six weeks before he was due to retire from the Senate, closed a long and distinguished career in State and Federal politics.

speech.para: Senator Reidshowed an early interest in government, and at the age of 21 years became the youngest shire councillor in New South Wales. He was subsequently deputy president of the Burrungong shire and an alderman of Murrumburrah. He was also closely associated with the Farmers and Settlers Association of New South Wales. In 1914 he joined the Australian Imperial Force and was in the first convoy to sail from Australia. He fought at Gallipoli and later served with the First and Fourth Light Horse Regiments in the Palestine campaign. As a captain, he won the Military Cross on 31st October, 1917, while leading the second squadron of the Fourth Light Horse Regiment in the famous charge at Beersheba, south of Damascus. For 4 miles he led his men against the Turkish defences in the face of heavy machine gun fire. In the words of the "Official History of Australia" in the 1914-18 War-

quote.para: Many horses in the leading line dropped but there was no check in the charge. The enemy fire served only to speed the gallop. The Turks, surprised and bewildered at the sheer audacity of the charge, failed to change the sights of their rifles, and for the last half mile their fire passed harmlessly overhead. From the time that the Fourth Light Horse received orders to saddle, to that of entry into Beersheba, less than an hour passed. It was a glorious hour filled not only with military achievement of a very rare kind, but with memorable deeds of individual officers and men which served vividly to demonstrate the spirit which alone made success possible.

speech.para: Field-Marshal Lord Allenby said -

quote.para: At Beersheba a mounted charge by a Light Horse Regiment, armed only with rides, swept across the Turkish trenches and decided the day.

speech.para: Later in the campaign,, on 30th September, 1918, when the Light Horse were racing for Damascus, Albert Reid, then a major, asked permission to charge with a few score of horsemen a column of Turks some thousands strong, but the commander of the Australian Mounted Division, Major-General H. W. Hodgson, restrained him. However, in the battle that followed a few hours later, Albert Reid's squadron charged with swords a position held by Germans across a wide stony valley. The Germans fled before Major Reid's horsemen reached their positions, thus ending bloodlessly one of the last enemy stands in the drive to Damascus.

In 1927, Albert Reid was elected to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly as Country Party member for Young. Though he lost the seat in 1930, he won it again in 1932, when he was appointed Country Party Whip. He was New South Wales Minister for Agriculture from 1938 to 1941. For a short period during 1941 he was Deputy Director of Recruiting in New South Wales. In the same year he joined the Second A.I.F., in which he served for two years. In 1949 he was elected to the Senate. He was Temporary Chairman of Committees in the Senate from 1951 to 1953, when he was appointed Chairman of Committees. During his nine years as
Chairmanof Committees he gained the respect of all senators for his impartiality and unfailing courtesy.
We extend our sympathy to his widow and his sons, Ian and Keith, and would have them know that this Senate will always honour the memory of Albert Reid.

talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democratic Labour Party
talker.name: COLE, George
Senator COLE

talk.start.para: . - There is little more that can be added to the splendid tributes that have been paid in the Senate this afternoon to the late Senator Reid. I join those who have already spoken in appreciation of his services. I extend to his family the sympathy of the Democratic Labour Party and support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Spooner).

- As one who was perhaps closer to the late Senator Reid than were other honorable senators, I wish to take this opportunity to express my sorrow at his passing. One of Senator Reid's chief characteristics was loyalty. Senator Spooner's remarks indicated the extent of Senator Reid's loyalty to his country and his service to it in World War I. and again in World War II. He served in the New South Wales Parliament before he became a member of the Senate. He was loyal to the members of the Senate. He was loyal to you, Sir, as President, and he was loyal to his many friends.

speech.para: During the recent recess, in a discussion about those who would not be returning to the Senate, I mentioned Senator Reid's unselfishness, another of his characteristics. I said then that he was the most unselfish man I had ever met, and I reiterate that statement to-day. He was held in very high esteem by all those who knew him in New South Wales. Reference has been made to the work that Senator Reid performed for his church. At the time of his death and for some years before, he was a member of the council of The Scots College, in Sydney. He had been vice-chairman of the New South Wales Country Party.

He leaves a family bereaved by his passing but comforted by the knowledge that he enjoyed a fine reputation. As I said when I last spoke about him, he left a family that would be a credit to any man and one of which he could well be proud.
Albert Reid has left in the minds of all of us the memory of a reputation that we may well envy.

talk.start.para: - I wish to add a few words to those that have already been spoken about the late Senator Albert Reid. I did not have the pleasure of knowing Senator Reid before 1949. However, I had heard of his work in the State Parliament of New South Wales, and of his war service. During the years in which 1 knew him after his entry into the Senate, we became very friendly indeed, and 1 would say that no man could wish for a better friend than Albert Reid. He did his utmost to make a success of any task which he undertook even though to do so might detrimentally affect his health. His ability to succeed in whatever he undertook was very well known. I take this opportunity to extend to his wife and family my deepest sympathy in their very sad bereavement.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, honorable senators standing in their places.
DEATH OF Mr. ALAN CHARLES BIRD, M.P.

Senator SPOONER(New South WalesVicePresident of the Executive Council and Minister for National Development). - by leave - It is with regret that 1 advise the Senate of the death on 21st July of Mr. Alan Charles Bird, a member of the House of Representatives. Mr. Bird was elected to the House of Representatives as member for the Division of Batman at the general election of 1949. He was a member of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works from 1951 to 1958, and he was Temporary Chairman of Committees from August, 1954, to November, 1955.

Although the late Mr. Bird died at the early age of 54, he had a long and distinguished career of service to the public not only in Parliament but also in the field of local government. We all remember his sense of responsibility and the way in which that was evidenced when he left his sick bed on 6th March last to fly to Canberra to be sworn in for his sixth term as a member of the House of Representatives. I feel that I cannot do better than recall the words of the Prime Minister (Mr.

Menzies), who described Mr. Bird, at the time of his death, as a fine representative of the Australian Parliament, a man of full experience, ingenuity and a personal integrity which impressed every one who came in contact with him.
I move -

quote.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death of Alan Charles Bird, member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Batman, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its sincere sympathy to his widow in her bereavement.

talk.start.para: - On behalf of the Opposition, I second the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Spooner). I do so because very early in life I was closely associated with the late Alan Bird. Our late colleague was one who, it can be truly said, spent a lifetime in the service of his fellows. As the Leader of the Government has said, he passed away in his early fifties. Even in that short span of life, he spent 32 years as a councillor in one of the important cities of Victoria. He was first elected to that office at the age of 24 and represented the same people in the council of that city at the time of his death. He became Mayor of the city first in the year 1939-40 and was again elected to that high office in the year 1958-59.

speech.para: As the Leader of the Government has said, he entered the Federal Parliament in 1949 following the retirement of the late Honorable Frank Brennan. In the twelve years during which Mr. Bird occupied the office of Federal representative I am confident no one could say that he did other than make friends. He certainly contributed to the dignity of the Parliament and took an extremely keen interest in its proceedings. Alan Bird made contributions on a wide range of subjects but, in the main, concentrated on two or three important matters. ' Finance for local government, repayment of petrol tax to the States, improved road construction, and the Colombo Plan featured again and again in his speeches. In some ways his career in Canberra was an extension of his work in the municipal sphere in the city in which he lived, for it was in Parliament that he voiced the difficulties of municipal management which he knew so intimately from practical experience. This interest in local government matters was not in any way a reflection of a limited vision. Rather did it spring from his profound understanding of and kinship with the people among whom he lived. Their difficulties were those of unemployment, housing, street construction, the provision of schools, hospitals, libraries and so on, that are so very close to the ordinary man. In Canberra, he advocated the imposition of a tax on diesel fuel, the return of the full amount of petrol tax to the States, and a fairer distribution of State allocations as between municipalities. Some of these things have been achieved, and much of the credit for their achievement must go to Alan Bird. From the first, he was a strong supporter of the move to establish the Preston-Northcote Community Hospital, and he played a very prominent part in persuading the State Government of the day to advance sufficient money to enable it to be completed.

Alan Bird was a conscientious member of this Parliament and always held himself available to help the people he represented. He was admired and respected for his great personal integrity, his compassion and his work to overcome those difficulties most closely touching the lives of the common man. In the death of Alan Bird, the Labour Party and this Parliament have suffered a great and serious loss. On behalf of his Senate colleagues, I tender our sin- ' cere sympathy to his widow.

Senator WADE(Victoria - Minister for Health). - Members of the Australian Country Party had a very high appreciation of the qualities that made Alan Bird such a distinguished Australian. He was a quietly spoken, sincere man who had a tremendously high appreciation of his civic responsibilities, and his contributions both in the National Parliament and in local government stamped him as a man who displayed vision and an understanding of the needs of the people whom he represented and who will always be grateful for his great work. Alan Bird was an ornament to the Parliament and the Australian Labour Party. We say to his sorrowing widow, his relatives and his colleagues of the Australian Labour Party that we would like to record our extreme regret at his untimely passing.

Senator COLE(Tasmania - Leader of the Australian Democratic Labour Party). - Mr. President, I support the tributes that have been paid to the late Mr. Alan Bird, To his widow I offer my sincere sympathy.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honorable senators standing in their places.

debateinfo.title: DEATHS OF FORMER MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

talker.role: Vice-President of the Executive Council and Minister for National Development
talker.name: SPOONER, William
Senator SPOONER

talk.start.para: . - by leave - Mr. President, I have moved two formal motions of condolence in respect of a senator and a member of the House of Representatives who died while they were members df this Parliament. Shortly I will suggest that, in accordance with our usual custom, the sitting of the Senate be suspended as a mark of respect to them.

speech.para: Before I do that I should like to mention three other people who have passed on since we last met, and who at one time were members of this Parliament although not members at the time of their death. I refer to Herbert Victor Johnson, George James Bowden and Rowland James. I wish to say » few words about each of them.

The Hon. Herbert Victor Johnson, who died on 10th July, was one of the distinguished members of the Australian Labour Party. He was a Minister of State. He held the portfolio of the Interior; he was Assistant Minister for Works and Housing; at one time he was Acting Attorney-General and at another time he was Acting Minister for External Affairs. His long record of service includes the chairmanship of the Board of Management of the Australian War Memorial from 1945 to 1949. He represented Kalgoorlie, Australia's largest electorate in area. He left behind him a great name in his State of Western Australia, and I hope that those who mourn him will take comfort in the thought that he was so well regarded in this Parliament during the years in which he was a member of it.

George James Bowden, a Victorian member of this Parliament, died on 8th June. He was elected for the division of Gippsland in 1943. He was another great parliamentarian. He was a Temporary Chairman of Committees from 1946 to 1958; a member of the Public Works Committee from 1950 to 1958; a member of the Standing Orders Committee of the House of Representatives, and a member of the select committee of the House of Representatives that was appointed to report on " Hansard ". Finally - this was his best-known work in the Parliament - he was Chairman of Committees in the House of Representatives from February, 1959 until he retired, on account of ill-health, in March, 1961.

It is rather coincidental that to-day we are paying tribute to two members of the Australian Country Party, each of whom was Chairman of Committees in his House of the Parliament and each of whom had a first-class war record. George Bowden was a captain in the 24th Battalion. He was awarded the Military Cross and was wounded three times during his period of service. Mr. President, 1 think we all would like his family to know that we remembered him at his passing and are conveying this token of our respect and, indeed, our affection for him.

I come now to Rowland James, who died on 4th July. He was elected for the division of Hunter at a general election in 1928. He also had a record of offices held. He was a member of the Public Works Committee - one of the important committees of this Parliament - from 1940 to 1946; he was chairman of that committee from 1943 to 1946, and a member of the Australian delegation to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in Nairobi. He is remembered as one of the most colourful personalities to come from New South Wales into this Parliament. He represented one of the big coal-mining constituencies for almost 30 years.

In the early days of my holding of my present portfolio, which includes administration of the Joint Coal Board, I went to Cessnock and other parts of the coalfields from time to time. Needless to say, my political views and those of Rowley James were very wide apart; but I always remember the way he went about introducing me to people whom he thought I should meet on the coalfields. He always tried to present me to those people in the best possible light. He was a friendly soul. I am glad to have an opportunity to put on record something of the feeling of friendship for him that I developed.

talk.start.para: . - Mr. President, I believe it was proper for the Leader of the. Government in the Senate (Senator Spooner) to advert to the recent deaths of three of our colleagues. Like him, I shall refer first to the Honorable Herbert Victor Johnson. All members of the Federal Parliamentary Labour Party were saddened by the news of the passing of our former colleague, who was known to us all as Vic Johnson. He was a colourful man who had had a colourful career. He was born in Western Australia. He commenced his working life as a drover and shearer. At the age of nineteen years he became a foundation member of the Australian Workers Union in his State. As an organizer for the pastoral section of his union, he visited every part of his far-flung State and was known from one end of it to the other. He had an intimate knowledge of the life and habits of the aborigines and of every phase of the great outback. Later he became State secretary of his union and for nine years from 1940 to 1949 he had the very great distinction of being its Federal president.

speech.para: It is not surprising that his association with that union - the most powerful as well as numerically the strongest union in Australia - should have led him into politics, because the Australian Workers Union played a vital part in the formation and development of the Australian Labour Party and still plays a vital role in the support of our party. Vic Johnson had a rapid rise in politics. He entered the Federal Parliament in November, 1940, and less than five years later had the rare privilege of being appointed a member of the national Government, the Chifley Government. Only sterling personal qualities enabled Vic Johnson to win through to the most honoured position in his union and to a Cabinet position. Outstanding amongst those qualities were his interest, his capacity for hard work, his sincere dedication to the cause of his fellow man, his fearlessness, his love of country, his modesty and the rugged Australianism that pervaded every fibre of his being. I recall that my experience of him in those years led me to remark on one occasion that if his veins were opened I would expect to find not blood, but eucalyptus oil. His mateship readily attracted him to the affectionate regard of others. His friends were legion.

I knew Vic Johnson from the day I entered the Parliament in July, 1944. I had the privilege of sitting next to him in the Chifley Cabinet for nearly four years. Vic Johnson's deep devotion to his religion and his life of service to others won for him a high place in his last and most important sphere - eternity. We revere his memory. To his widow, affectionately known to nearly all of us, and to the members of his family we extend our warmest sympathy, and trust that they will be given the strength to bear their deep sorrow.

Like Senator Spooner, I too refer to the death of George James Bowden, M.C. Just as all members of the Opposition regretted the obvious and rapid deterioration in health of Mr. Bowden, which preceded his retirement in December last, they regret also that he was spared for so brief a time after his retirement. As- was Senator Spooner, I was struck this afternoon by the many points of similarity between Senator Reid and Mr. Bowden. Both had distinguished military careers in two world wars; both won the Military Cross. One was Chairman of Committees in the House of Representatives and the other Chairman of Committees in the Senate. Both were members of the Country Party. They died within a short time of each other, and the death of each is the subject of reference this afternoon in the Senate.

More important, both men were cast in the same mould of character that I described earlier to-day when referring to Senator Reid. In saying that, I pay the highest tribute to Mr. Bowden. I should like to have known Mr. Bowden better. Unfortunately, our different spheres of activity prevented that, and now it is no longer possible. We of the Opposition in the Senate extend our condolences to the members of the Country Party in the loss of their highly esteemed colleague. We extend to his sorrowing relatives our deep sympathy in their great loss.

I comment now on the regrettable death of Rowland James. The late Rowley James, as we knew him, was a member of the Australian Labour Party and one of the most picturesque and strongly marked personalities to pass through the portals of this Parliament. He represented the coalmining constituency of Hunter from 1928 until his retirement in 1958 He waged, with vigour, ability and success, an unceasing fight for better wages and conditions for coal miners. He rendered invaluable and devoted service to the nation by acting as liaison officer between the Curtin Government and later the Chifley Government, .and the coal-mining industry from 1943 to 1949. That was a period of the gravest difficulty in the the industry.

Mr. Jameswas as strong in body as he was in mind. We believed that he was indestructible but, unfortunately, injuries received in a road accident impaired his physique and caused him distress in his latest years. Despite his toughness in debate and his forthright speech he was a hearty and amiable companion, as Senator Spooner earlier remarked. In truth, no more tender-hearted man existed. He was the soul of generosity to any one in distress. He gave the most loyal and valuable service to his party and to the nation. It consoles us to think that his spirit will live on in this Parliament, since his son is present member for Hunter. The spirit and tradition of Rowley James will survive. We offer to his widow and the members of his family our sincere sympathy in their grievous loss.

talk.start.para: . - The Country Party joins with previous speakers in the tributes paid to Mr. Bowden, Mr. Johnson and Mr. James. Each in his own capacity served this nation and Parliament well. They will be remembered for the contribution that they made to a better way of life in this country. To those who are left to mourn their passing we extend our very sincere sympathy.

talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democratic Labour Party
talker.name: COLE, George
Senator COLE

talk.start.para: . - I join in the tributes paid by other honorable members to our former colleagues of the Federal Parliament and I offer my sincerest sympathy to their sorrowing families.

- For the first time in the nearly thirteen years that I have been in this Parliament I join in expressions of condolence. In passing, I ask: Does it not strike us how individual in character and personality were these men of whom we are speaking? I wish to refer to one man in particular - the late Victor Johnson. I had known and been associated with Vic Johnson for almost the whole of my life - ever since I was a small boy. Our families were firm friends; his son, Mervyn, who predeceased him by only ten days, was a constant visitor to our town and stayed at our home.

speech.para: I have seen Victor Johnson under many stresses and strains over a long period. After I entered this Parliament I worked with him in organizing, and was associated with him before that. With due deference to all those people with whom I have been associated in organizing work, Vic Johnson stands out as the best natural organizer of them all. He had an innate ability to get things done.

We have heard the record read to us by Senator McKenna and referred to by Senator Spooner, but the official record does not bring out the fact that the passing of Victor Johnson marked the end of an era, such as we shall never see again. The record does not show that the whole of his schooling amounted, in broken periods, to a total of eighteen months. At the age of twelve he was away from home, first working at a station in the Hamelin Pool district. On his twenty-first birthday he shore 200 sheep and so rose into that select coterie of shearers known as " deuce-'em " artists, and so became one of the highest class of shearers.

Vic Johnson told me on many occasions that after he became secretary of the pastoral section of the Australian Workers Union his education was continued by an old man who took an interest in him and made him at night write out the leading article in " The West Australian ". Then the next morning, before work, he would dictate it back to his mentor, who would correct his pronunciation, tell him the meaning of words and so on. I do not suppose that we will ever again find a man with that background - a man whose university training, as it were, was gained in the negotiations on industrial disputes and in appearances before judges of the arbitration courts who were dealing with mining strikes, shearing disputes and such matters - rising to the position attained by Victor Johnson.

I remember him vividly in the 1930 shearers' strike, when sixteen men were sentenced to gaol for a period of two months as a result of their actions during the strike. Victor Johnson went to a nonLabour attorney-general in Western Australia who, in his wisdom, immediately allowed the men out of gaol after they had served a total of only eight days. One of my prized possessions to-day is the book that they wrote, called " The Gaol Echo ". I do not suppose that it has had a very wide distribution, but it is interesting now to look through it reminiscently and see the photographs of Victor Johnson in it. Characteristically, I was with Victor Johnson when he entered on his most controversial role in recent years, which was over-played in press reports immediately prior to his death, and following it. I was with him in Kalgoorlie on an organizing campaign when he criticized his own leader in a public press statement which caused so much interest and controversy throughout Australia. I suppose it was characteristic that I should be with him following a long association which started when he and my father became friends. Both he and my father were men who knew what mateship meant. After the death of my father the association continued with me, who, of course, was a younger man. I have heard a number of versions of this incident. I mention it to-day not to rake over old ashes or coals. Every one of the versions I have heard has been false. I was in Victor Johnson's company during the three preceding days. He told me that he was going to make the statement and forthwith made it. He sought no advice from anybody and asked for no comment. It was typical of his bigness that when he was determined to do a thing he thrust the responsibility on nobody else.

Let me mention another of Victor Johnson's characteristics which might help honorable senators to understand him better. He was incapable of holding any doubt within his breast. He had to dispel it. Many times in this Parliament he came to me to challenge me or inquire about something I had said which he did not understand, or which did not quite please him. Friends as we were, he could not have anything on his mind without bringing it into the open. Whatever anybody might think of the wisdom or otherwise of his statement in the heat of those days, nevertheless he had to make it. As we are paying our final tribute to Victor Johnson I should like to put these remarks on record because I was the only person who was with him at that time. I repeat that he asked no advice and made the statement completely on his own responsibility. He sought to lean on nobody, and I know that he did what he did with a full sense of responsibility. He made the statement in the town of Kalgoorlie which was the head-quarters of his electorate because he felt that he owed it to the Australian electors to make his position clear.

I know of his preoccupation during the preceding two or three days as he thought over 50 years of active work in the Australian Labour movement in both the industrial and political spheres and looked back through the vista of those years. He realized the troubles the movement was passing through; he knew full well that in spite of 50 years' association with the Labour movement he could well end his life outside the movement and apart from the things for which he had devoted half a century of his lifetime. Fortunately that did not happen. I feel that a great deal of misunderstanding arose over the incident. I mention these things not to rake over dead ashes or to revive a controversy that is now over, but simply to put the record straight and enable people to understand that he did what he did because his conscience dictated such action.

Finally, I do not think we can refer to the life of Victor Johnson without alluding to his love of Australian poets, particularly Henry Lawson. Those poems engendered in him a nostalgia for the old days. He loved particularly two poems. One was " Bourke ", from which he would often recite the lines -

quote.para: They drank - when all is said and done - they gambled, and their speech was rough;
You'd only need to say of one " He was my mate !"
But hint a bushman was not white, nor to his Union straight and true -
Twould mean a long and bloody fight in Ninety-one and Ninety-two.

speech.para: Vic loved that poem because he was part of that era. He came over from that industrial era which began with the strikes of '91 and 92 and continued to the early part of this century. Almost invariably - and I suppose I have heard him recite these poems more times than I care to count - he would finish up on the lighter poem of "Sweeney ".
I think this poem brought back to Victor the nostalgia for the old days. He would recite this verse -

quote.para: And of afternoons in cities, when the rain is on the land,
Visions come to me of Sweeney with his bottle in his hand,
With the stormy night behind him, and the pub verandah-post -
And I wonder why he haunts me more than any other ghost.

speech.para: He did not learn those poems in the schoolroom, because he seldom saw the inside of a schoolroom. He learnt them at the time when Lawson's poems were published in the " Bulletin ". He learnt them in the cool of bark huts and in the shearing sheds. He had an amazing memory and often recited poems that I have never seen in print. I suppose they were published in the " Bulletin " in those days.

Let me say a final word about Victor Johnson. I look back to the friendship of our families, the friendship between my father and Victor and his close association with me over the years. Of all the people I have known and of all the people who have passed through this Parliament my memory of him will haunt me more than any other ghost.

talk.start.para: -I desire to associate myself with this motion of condolence on the passing of three very respected members of this Parliament. I was very closely associated with Mr. H. V. -Victor - Johnson. When we express our sympathy to his widow we address a very gracious lady. I think that Victor would have me say that a great deal of what he achieved in his career was due to the help given him by Mrs. Johnson. This grand woman stood for the same spirit of mateship that Victor personified during the whole of his life. His family life was characterized by love and respect. Because of his public commitments as an organizer and reformer and a worker for the betterment of the people of Australia his family had to make sacrifices. I was president of the Labour movement when Victor Johnson entered this Parliament. He had no ambition for politics, but stood for election as a result of an approach made by the then Labour Prime Minister of Australia who suggested to Victor that it would be better if he left his industrial associations and entered this Parliament.

speech.para: Victor Johnson could hold his place in any company. When the Earl of Listowel visited this country, when he was the Labour Party Whip in the House of Lords, he spent a lot of time in the company of Victor Johnson. He appreciated his basic Australianism, his absolute inherent honesty and his desire without any garnishings to do the right thing. I went with Victor Johnson on a good-will visit to Portuguese Timor and Dutch Timor at the time when the islands of Cartier and Ashmore were taken over by Australia from the United Kingdom. Victor Johnson met the people he had to meet on their own level and created great respect and understanding for Australia and Australianism.

I think the greatest thing we can say of Victor Johnson is that he had a great appreciation of mateship whether in war or peace. His sacrifice on behalf of the people he represented industrially and politically was made unselfishly. Senator Willesee referred to a time, which some of us remember, when strikers were gaoled for attempting to improve their industrial conditions. Victor Johnson made a submission to the Attorney-General of Western Australia to have those men released from prison because they were imprisoned for striking for just conditions. Without rest, he rode a bicycle 600 miles from northern Australia to Perth in a period that was thought impossibly short in those days. Upon arrival in Perth he presented his case to the Parliament. This occasion was a milestone in the advance of industrial conditions. Victor Johnson will be sadly missed. He was respected both by those with whom he was associated here and by those whose conditions he helped to improve.

I also had the privilege of friendship with George Bowden and I admired him. He worked sincerely for the party that he represented and, in accordance with his conscience, for the benefit of the people of Australia.

Rowley James was at one time associated with Western Australian coal mines but was, of course, better known in the eastern States. He was another pioneer of our industrial history. He lived through those times when it was not popular to be a Labour man and a supporter of an industrial union. He was a pioneer in the achievement of improved industrial conditions. Many people have now forgotten the sacrifices of those who fought that fight. In those early days it was common to regard Labour men as not having the highest regard for their nation and to deride them merely because they were reformers, seeking better conditions. Victor Johnson and Rowley James were reformers and pioneers, and were respected in that field of Australia's advancement.

I associate myself sincerely with the expressions of sadness at the passing of three great Australians whom we held in the highest respect and I extend my condolences to the bereaved members of their families.
